history.narrative: Law 10-26, the “Carjacking Prevention Amendment Act of 1993,” was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 10-16, which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on April 7, 1993, and May 4, 1993, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on May 19, 1993, it was assigned Act No. 10-28 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 10-26 became effective on October 2, 1993.

meta.search-text: kwiktag 062 313 826 COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA NOTICE D.C. LAW I0-26 "Carjacking Prevention Amendment Act of 1993 Pursuant to Section 412 of the District of Columbia Self-Government and Governmental Reorganization Act, P, L, 93-198 the Act the Council of the District of Columbia adopted Bill No. lO-16 on first and second readings, April 7, 1993, and May 4, 1993, respectively. Following the signature of the Mayor on May 19, 1993, this legislation was assigned Act No, I0-28, published in the May 28, 1993, edition of the D.C. Register Vol 40 page 3416) and transmitted to Congress on May 26, 1993 for a 60-day review, in accordance with Section 602(c)(2) of the Act. The Council of the District of Columbia hereby gives notice that the 60-day Congressional Review Period has expired, and therefore, cites this enactment as D,C, Law 10-26, effective 0c~2, 19 DAVID A. CLARKE Chairman of the Council Dates Counted During the 60-day Congressional Review Period: May June July August September October 26,27,28 7,8,9,10,II,14,15,16,17,18,21,22,23,24,25,28,29,30 1,13,14,15,16,19,20,21,22,23,26,27,28,29,30 2,3,4,5,6 7,8,9,10,13,14,15,16,17,20,21,22,23,24,27,28,29,30 l AN ACT D,C, ACT i0-28 Enrolled Original Coditlc on IN THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTI~ICT OF COLUMBIA MAY 19, 1993 To amend An Act to establish a code of law for the District of Columbia and to amend section 23-1331(4) of the District of Columbia Code to create the criminal offense of carjacking. BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTI~ICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Carjacking Prevention Amendment Act of 1993 Sec. 2. An Act to establish a code of law for the District of Columbia, approved March 3, 1901 (31 Star. 1322; D.C. Code § 22-2901 e~ seq is amended by adding a new section 811a to read as follows See. 811a. Carjacking a)(1) A person commits the offense of earjaeking if, by any means, that person knowingly or recklessly by force or violence, whether against resistance or by sudden or stealthy seizure or snatching, or by putting in fear, or attempts to do so, shall take from another person immediate actual possession of a person’s motor vehicle 2) A person convicted of earjaeking shall be fined not more than $5,000 and be imprisoned for a mandatory-minimum term of not less than 7 years and a maximum term of not more than 21 years, or both b)(1) A person commits the offense of armed earjaeking if that person while armed with or having readily available any pistol or other firearm (or imitation thereof) or other dangerous or deadly weapon (including a sawed-off shotgun, shotgun, machine gun, rifle, dirk, bowie knife, butcher knife, switch-blade knife, razor, blackjack, billy or metallic, or other false knuckles) commits or attempts to commit the offense of earjaeking 2) A person convicted of armed earjaeking shall be fined not more than $10,000 and be imprisoned for a mandatory-minimum term of not less than 15 years and a maximum term of not more than 45 years, or both See. 3. Section 23-1331(4) of the District of Columbia Code is amended by inserting the phrase "armed carjacking after the phrase "assault with a dangerous weapon See. 4. Section 8 of the District of Columbia Good Times Credit Act of 1986, effective April 11, 1987 (D.C. Law 6-218; D.C. Code § 24-434 is amended by inserting the phrase "and 811a" after the phrase New Section 22-2903 Section 23-1331 Section 24-434 Enrolled Original "section 801" and inserting the phrase "and § 22-2903 (1993 Supp after the phrase "§ 22-2404(b Sec. 5. This act shall take effect after a 60-day period of Congressional review following approval by the Mayor (or in the event of veto by the Mayor, action by the Council of the District of Columbia to override the veto) as provided in section 602(c)(2) of the District of Columbia Self-Government and Governmental Reorganization Act, approved December 24, 1973 (87 Star. 813; D.C. Code § 1-233(c)(2 and publication in either the District of Columbia Register, the District of Columbia Statutes-at-Large, or the District of Columbia Municipal Regulations.
